newsitem.title: GERMANY: German Bunds retreat from highs but remain cheery.
newsitem.headline: German Bunds retreat from highs but remain cheery.

text.p: German debt prices enjoyed an early rally on Wednesday, cheered by a relatively tame speech by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan late on Tuesday.

But after the September DTB Bund future powered to a new contract high at 103.58 in early trade, prices settled back slightly in later trade with the contract at 103.21, up 21 basis points, by 1512 GMT.
"The market was very strong after Greenspan, but things have calmed down a bit now," said one Frankfurt-based trader.
Analysts said inflation data from three west German states had taken a bit of the shine off the debt price rally.
The states of Hesse, Bavaria and North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany's most populated states, all said the cost of living had increased in July.
Prices in all three states were up 0.5 percent on the month, while year-on-year rates ranged from up 1.7 percent to up 2.1 percent.
But despite the rise, which some analysts said was partly fuelled by mark weakness, economists said there was no reason to fear a monetary tightening from the Bundesbank.
The central bank holds it regular fortnightly meeting in Frankfurt on Thursday.
"There is no need to panic," said Holger Fahrinkrug, senior Germany economist at UBS in Frankfurt. "The Bundesbank will do nothing for some time to come."
A Reuters poll of 10 economists showed that not one expects a change in key Lombard, discount or repo rates at the meeting.

But some traders said that another sharp downwards move in the mark's exchange rate versus the dollar might fuel renewed speculation further that the Bundesbank might consider moving to a variable repo rate or even raising the rate.
"With the mark taking a beating, people will be looking at whether the Bundesbank might moveon the repo," said one.
The mark traded as low as 1.8325 to the dollar on Wednesday after Greenspan's speech boosted Wall Street and prompted enthusiasm for U.S. assets.
By 1552 GMT the German currency was in slightly better shape, trading at 1.8235 to the dollar.
Analysts said the Bund market might be slightly unsettled by the currency's weakness in the coming sessions, but would continue to be well-supported by firmer U.S. markets.
